conversation.content: [meow] Is that a tuxedo? Are you seriously wearing a tuxedo to a mud run?
It's a rental, actually. Lost a bet with my investment team last quarter, and here we are. They said formal attire or forfeit my parking spot for a year.
That's insane. You're gonna destroy that thing in the first obstacle.
Already put down the damage deposit. Figured if I'm going to look ridiculous, might as well commit fully to the aesthetic.
Wait, are those cufflinks?
Platinum family heirlooms, yeah. My grandmother would probably haunt me if she knew, but she also taught me never to back down from a challenge.
You can't be serious.
The way I see it, everyone else is trying to look athletic and prepared. I'm providing entertainment value and raising money for the children's hospital, so why not make it memorable?
I'm Sarah, by the way. Team Mud Missiles.
Alexander, but everyone calls me Lex. Flying solo today because my teammates chickened out when they saw the weather forecast.
The lightning warning?
That's the one. Apparently crawling through electrified mud pits during a potential thunderstorm wasn't covered in their liability waivers. Can't say I blame them, but the show must go on.
You're either brave or completely unhinged.
Probably both. My therapist says I have issues with risk assessment, but she also runs ultramarathons, so I take that with a grain of salt.
So what happens when you hit the cargo net in that getup?
[clearing throat] I've actually been practicing in my backyard. The jacket tears awayâ€”it's held together with velcro. The pants, unfortunately, are staying intact for modesty's sake.
This is the weirdest pre-race conversation I've ever had.
[condescending] You should hear my strategy for the tire run. It involves a physics equation and what I call the pendulum principle of mud displacement.
Are you making this up as you go?
[singing] Absolutely making it up, every single word, but confidence is half the battle in these things, wouldn't you agree?
